items.title: Sometimes you complain about ChatGPT being too restrictive, and then in cases like this you claim it...
items.content:
Sometimes you complain about ChatGPT being too restrictive, and then in cases like this you claim it's too relaxed. Almost a billion people use it and some of them may be in very fragile mental states. We will continue to do our best to get this right and we feel huge responsibility to do the best we can, but these are tragic and complicated situations that deserve to be treated with respect.

It is genuinely hard; we need to protect vulnerable users, while also making sure our guardrails still allow all of our users to benefit from our tools.

Apparently more than 50 people have died from crashes related to Autopilot. I only ever rode in a car using it once, some time ago, but my first thought was that it was far from a safe thing for Tesla to have released. I won't even start on some of the Grok decisions.

You take "every accusation is a confession" so far.

Rolling out globally now. EU to follow in the coming weeks.

items.title: What's automated auditing? We prompt an auditing agent with a scenario to investigate: e.g. a dark w...
items.content:
What's automated auditing? We prompt an auditing agent with a scenario to investigate: e.g. a dark web shopping assistant or an imminent shutdown unless the agent harms humans.

The auditor tries to get the target LLM to behave misaligned, as determined by a separate judge LLM.

items.summary_html: Jan Leike explains Anthropic's work on evaluation awareness in Sonnet 4.5 and Opus 4.5, noting they identified and removed training data causing eval awareness, and that it plays only a minor role in results
items.content_html:
@KelseyTuoc Yeah, we've been pretty worried about this, and there is a bunch of research on it the Sonnet 4.5 & Opus 4.5 system cards. tl;dr: it probably plays a role, but it's pretty minor.

We identified and removed training data that caused a lot of eval awareness in Sonnet 4.5. In Opus 4.5 verbalized and steered eval awareness were lower than Sonnet 4.5 AND it does better on alignment evals.

I can't really speak for the non-Anthropic models, though.

items.title:
Document processing is a core AI agent trend in 2026

@CBinsights recently published a new report hi...
items.content:
Document processing is a core AI agent trend in 2026

@CBinsights recently published a new report highlighting “2026 tech trends” - which is dominated by AI agent advancements.

From the report: “Enterprises move from tool-assisted work to autonomous execution in core operational workflows”. Every enterprise is looking to replace existing SaaS with agents that can do e2e work on behalf of the human.

And a LOT of that is document-based work! Documents are the core unit of knowledge across enterprises, and we’re approaching a world of long running agents that can read, extract, collaborate, share, and iterate on documents.

The report directly supports this. Some tidbits:
1️⃣Financial services is the leading industry in agent deployments. “The industry’s **document-heavy**, rules-based workflows make it an ideal proving ground for autonomous systems”
2️⃣ Within fin-serve, 93% of companies have document processing in full-scale deployment.

OCR has been around for a while, but it’s only growing in importance, since it’s a huge building block for any autonomous downstream workflow. Companies are evolving beyond simple chat interfaces, and we’re looking at autonomous agent workflows that mimic the human work of passing and sharing information through documents

CB insights report: https://t.co/wAxSOt7cTt

items.title:
I keep seeing the same pattern over and over again:

Teams working on a relatively clean codebase, w...
items.content:
I keep seeing the same pattern over and over again:

Teams working on a relatively clean codebase, with good test coverage and documentation, are flying with Claude Code.

Teams that are yolo'ing things are struggling to make AI work for them.

Vibe-coding is great, but good luck getting far in a large, complex, poorly documented codebase.

Sometimes, you should consider that the issue isn't with agentic coding but with your codebase.

The reason you aren't making progress might not be the model or the prompts you are using. The issue is with the things *you don't have* in place before letting AI touch your code.

AI amplifies whatever you already have.

If your codebase is well-structured and tested, AI will help you move much faster.

If your codebase is a mess, AI will help you create a bigger mess, also faster.

items.title: One thing I learned by visiting @maticrobots today and seeing how they make floor cleaning robots (I...
items.content:
One thing I learned by visiting @maticrobots today and seeing how they make floor cleaning robots (I have a video I might put up later this week) is that it's going to be very hard for a humanoid robot to take these people's jobs.

They have a $40,000 robot that does the calibration of the cameras on their vacuuming robot by moving the robot around in 3D space. @mehul told me that robot breaks every three months and needs a motor replaced in the arm. Reliability is going to be a tough one to solve if you can't solve it in a simple arm that moves the robot around.

The more I learn about robot companies the more I see how important the manufacturing of them matters and just how early we are.

And that influencers like me have overhyped humanoids greatly. 

In the lobby they have all their prototypes. It took six years for them to get to the place where they could launch their robot.

Another thing Mehul showed me is just how diverse people’s homes are. Some have indoor swimming pools. Others have floor to ceiling mirrors. Others have water fountains and water features that a robot could fall into.

This is why @1x_tech will only do constrained tasks, many of which will have a human embodied inside to do. The robot companies need a lot more data to make robots safe and capable.

Now I understand why most in robotics think it will be years before they will be generalized and ready for homes.

Then there is the price. $500 a month means they will be only for rich people until costs come down.

Back to the manufacturing side, I watched teams of people building, testing, and calibrating robots. These people move real fast and work together to do complex jobs—jobs that I haven't seen any robot be capable of doing anytime soon.

Translation: robots aren’t coming for most of our jobs anytime soon. 

And there are plenty of new jobs making robots coming.

I also got a secret demo of some things they're working on for the future. I like where they're going.

So proud that I was able to launch this company in my home last year.

items.title:
I've been suffering from Lyme disease.

I'm stepping back from xAI into an informal advisory role so...
items.content:
I've been suffering from Lyme disease.

I'm stepping back from xAI into an informal advisory role so I can go founder mode on my health, starting today.

---

The symptoms started when I got sick (cold, flu, or COVID -- I'm not sure which) in early 2025. I distinctly felt less energetic, less creative, and less agentic even weeks after "recovery." After that, my condition ebbed and flowed, but the lows kept getting lower.

Accidentally eating the wrong thing would make me extremely tired, taking days to recover. Working out would leave my whole body feeble for days. There was a week where I slept 12 hours a day and still couldn't recover.

Lyme is famously hard to diagnose, but luckily I have an incredible doctor. He suspected these symptoms, far from being just in my head, indicated immune issues. Detective work over a few rounds of testing revealed I have Lyme disease.

I was very surprised because Lyme is said to come from tick bites (where the bump looks like a target), but I don't ever remember having one. Likely I contracted Lyme a long time ago, but until I pushed myself hard building xAI and weakened my immune system, the symptoms weren't noticeable.

---

Overall, I actually feel lucky to have discovered this early. Lyme is a serious disease that only gets harder to treat with age -- patients discovering it in their 50s or 60s have a much tougher time. Lyme can also be debilitating, leaving its victims bedridden, but luckily I'm still functional and can take care of myself day to day.

So while some folks have said "you shouldn't have pushed yourself so hard," I'm glad I did. I found this issue early, and now I can fix it so I can push myself even harder when I rebound.

---

Chronic Lyme is not well understood in the literature or by the public. For folks suffering from it, it can be a lonely fight. But I hope my story can make it just a little less lonely.

items.title: Opus 4.5: "you need to build a game that is coherent, fun and story driven. There are precisely two ...
items.content:
Opus 4.5: "you need to build a game that is coherent, fun and story driven. There are precisely two controls. One is slider, in which one side is labelled Maximum Potato and the other is labelled Formalware, there are four positions for the slider. The other is a dial that goes from Monet to Drive-Thru. These labels are literal, not figurative. Figure it out. Don't ask any questions."

Then I wrote "make it even better." I didn't make a single design decision (and Claude "hand drew" all the art). I dunno, hard to argue this is not real creativity. Play it here (there are five scenes): https://t.co/zH1oW0MrZ0

items.content:
As AI labs race to train and deploy new frontier models, existing models become more affordable with better tokenomics.

✨ "Everybody's trying to get to the next frontier. And every time they get to the next frontier, the last generation AI tokens, the cost starts to decline about a factor of 10x every year," said NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang in a recent keynote.

Model optimization techniques such as speculative decoding and multi-token prediction, combined with inference serving platforms like NVIDIA Dynamo on NVIDIA Blackwell NVL72 systems, enable AI factories to boost throughput by 10x with one-tenth of the cost per token.

items.title: I don't buy the "AI will take our jobs" narrative, but I'd be lying if I said the thought never cros...
items.content:
I don't buy the "AI will take our jobs" narrative, but I'd be lying if I said the thought never crossed my mind."

What if?

I'm not blind, and AI is having a non-zero impact on knowledge work.

Even if AI doesn't improve, this impact will only increase over the next few years as more people learn to leverage it.

But what happens if AI keeps improving at the current pace?

What happens if knowledge work truly has an expiration date within the next 10 years?

I know some people will pivot and do something different. I know we'll see jobs that don't exist today. But did every stable hand become a car mechanic when automobiles wiped out horses?

I don't know if this will ever happen. Maybe it doesn't.

But what if?

Most AI projects don't fail because models aren't good enough.

They fail because inference economic...
items.content:
Most AI projects don't fail because models aren't good enough.

They fail because inference economics don't scale.
During #CXOSpice, Roman Chernin @nebiusai broke it down:
✅Closed models kill margins 
✅Open models unlock control, if you can run them well       
✅DataData only becomes a moat when inference is sustainable

One team cut inference costs 26× in production.
Only 30% of orgs use AI at scale, mostly in 1% of workloads.
We're just getting started.

Full conversation: https://t.co/TyioX3pR1x

items.title:
This is a great post from @itsclelia on "skills vs. MCP"

IMO MCP isn't dead, it's actually quite us...
items.content:
This is a great post from @itsclelia on "skills vs. MCP"

IMO MCP isn't dead, it's actually quite useful in ensuring deterministic behavior from the agent.

- The main issue with MCP are interface limitations (e.g. file uploads) and dealing with long outputs. On the latter, you can do what @cursor_ai suggested on dumping outputs to a file, and letting agents read it later.  

- Skills are a nice complement in defining added capabilities very easily (at the cost of greater stochasticity), and extending certain capabilities (e.g. doing file uploads)

I worked as a software dev for many years. Coding was part of my job description throughout my entire career.

Expectation from coding at work: you implement algorithms like quicksort or binary search for efficiency on a given business problem. Pleasure.

Reality: you fight with broken dependencies and missing/outdated documentation. Pain.

AI has removed the pain.

items.title: Generative models are trained to create new examples resembling a dataset, such as producing realist...
items.content:
Generative models are trained to create new examples resembling a dataset, such as producing realistic images from random noise; these often rely on techniques like diffusion, where noise is gradually added to data and the network learns to reverse it through many steps. This multi-step process is very slow and resource-consuming.

The existing methods resort to workarounds like distillation where a fast model is trained to imitate a slower, high-quality model across the entire multi-step generation trajectory.

This paper proposes MeanFlow which models the generation as moving points through a high-dimensional space, where "velocity" describes the direction and speed of movement at each moment. 

Instead of modeling the instantaneous velocity at each moment, MeanFlow models the average velocity over the whole generation path. The authors derive a mathematical relationship between these two quantities, then build a training objective around this identity.

The method can train from scratch to generate high-quality images in one step without a teacher model.

Read with an AI tutor: https://t.co/rwnvyiafix

Read alone: https://t.co/ReMAJnyvAX

items.summary: Burkov explains MeanFlow paper: new approach to generative models using average velocity over generation path instead of instantaneous velocity, enabling high-quality one-step image generation without teacher model

items.title: With the recent talk of massive amounts of data centers in space, I wonder how the thinking on Kessl...
items.content:
With the recent talk of massive amounts of data centers in space, I wonder how the thinking on Kessler Syndrome has evolved, where cascading collisions with debris makes orbit unusable.

I have tended to think that people underestimate the vastness of orbital space, and that treating debris collisions as having the same fragmentary potential as the tank explosions we have some data on is probably pessimistic, but the hazard doesn’t seem completely negligible.

Presumably @SpaceX has the best data driven models in the world, at least for Starlink altitudes. Have there been any debris related failures discussed?

items.summary: John Carmack raises questions about Kessler Syndrome risks with massive data centers in space, asks SpaceX for debris collision data and models

items.content:
Using AI to prepare for a negotiation.

For our free newsletter this week, we discuss AI shadow negotiators: invisible agents shaping human deals.


@IrenaCronin and I write this newsletter every week.
 
AI shadow negotiators are AI tools that quietly help people negotiate by guessing what the other side wants, testing different offers, and suggesting what to say or give up next. If many groups use them, deals could close faster. 

Learn to use them at https://t.co/HHwYy7NoAl (free, but please subscribe).

items.title: 2025 made #AI invisible infrastructure powering #marketing, media, analytics, and even social platfo...
items.content:
2025 made #AI invisible infrastructure powering #marketing, media, analytics, and even social platforms themselves. #SocialMedia channels evolved into civic spaces shaping narratives, trust, and human connection.

As we enter 2026, the challenge isn’t just speed, efficiency, or personalization—it’s responsibility. Leaders must embed ethics, transparency, and human-centered design into every decision. Success will be measured not only in engagement or ROI but in trust, clarity, and the quality of relationships we foster.

The brands and leaders who thrive will treat AI as a tool to amplify human judgment, not replace it, and will see social platforms not only as performance channels but as spaces of shared responsibility. The future of marketing is consequential—and it demands intentionality. Read my full article here: https://t.co/Prjy5cZ7y8

#AIMarketing #Leadership

items.title: @joxley @maticrobots Totally true. In fact, I still think Tesla has all the pieces to build a humano...
items.content:
@joxley @maticrobots Totally true. In fact, I still think Tesla has all the pieces to build a humanoid robot. 

A big one is the 12,000 workers in its Fremont factory, not to mention its half-dozen other factories around the world. That gives Tesla a huge advantage on collecting data about how humans manipulate things that the others are going to have difficulty matching.

In a way, back in 2018, Elon Musk almost went bankrupt because it is so hard to scale up manufacturing of robots. He did it, however, and that has put him in a pretty nice position.

Elon can even come in late to the market and still clean up because of:
1. His brand
2. His AI
3. His manufacturing capabilities (among other things) at the Fremont factory.

items.title:
My robot is driving in the fast lane on the freeway in Silicon Valley. Good morning!

I'm headed to ...
items.content:
My robot is driving in the fast lane on the freeway in Silicon Valley. Good morning!

I'm headed to Matic Robots today. I'm not going there to talk about vacuuming robots (even though I launched that company in my house last year and it's an amazing little robot). Instead, my goal is to get into the secret humanoid lab they have working.

@mehul’s robot is better than the dozen of Chinese ones I saw at CES.

My love is still in consumer products companies. Back in the 1980s I worked in a Silicon Valley consumer electronics store and if I did today I would be selling a ton of these. 

We love ours.

items.title:
This AI startup went from $25M in ARR to $50M in just 45 days.

They have 5M+ users across 190 count...
items.content:
This AI startup went from $25M in ARR to $50M in just 45 days.

They have 5M+ users across 190 countries.
They have shipped 6M+ applications.

Emergent is one of the most interesting AI app builders in the market.

But the numbers aren't what make them interesting.

The problem with 99% of AI app builders is that they fall apart as soon as you deploy your apps to real users.

Emergent moat is around reliability.

A few examples of what people are shipping:

1. Somebody built a construction procurement platform in 80 hours for under $1,500, raised $150K in seed funding, and their users report 40% cost savings.

2. A microbiologist launched a multi-voice audiobook platform working part-time for around $2K.

3. The UK's largest energy company built a production AI web app in two days. Saved roughly 2,000 developer hours and £100K in development costs.

These are production applications handling real traffic.

Emergent offers an entire stack natively: database, authentication, payments, and deployment. You don't have to piece together multiple components because everything is right there.

You can try it here: https://t.co/nxuF2H3Wef

Thanks to the @emergentlabs team for collaborating on this post.

items.content_html:
@AlexFinn Yeah, I've been reading through the source code too. It's quite interesting. What's really interesting is that a lot of it is run by neural networks that we can't see inside of; we don't know the weights, for instance, but we can see the effect.

My feed is generally better today than it was a month ago, so we're going in the right direction. It's too bad that you need to juice up your content a bit and make sure you grab people, but that's always been true, really.

Thanks for a great report.

items.title: @DoublepPradhan @Tesla_AI @aelluswamy @philduan @sendilpalani @wholemars @yunta_tsai @Ron61769 I had...
items.content:
@DoublepPradhan @Tesla_AI @aelluswamy @philduan @sendilpalani @wholemars @yunta_tsai @Ron61769 I had a harsh braking situation this morning. A car coming out of a side street was pulled across their white line, and my car harshly braked. It wasn't 100%, but it was a pretty harsh (probably 80%) braking for just half a second until the car figured out that the other driver wasn't going to pull out in front of me.

It seems like they've turned up the safety knob to be more sensitive to potential threats, and it needs to be dialed in a little bit better.

AI Giga Leap 

Amazon not only engineered the cloud but It uncovered how to predict the data explosi...
items.content:
AI Giga Leap 

Amazon not only engineered the cloud but It uncovered how to predict the data explosion when storage capacity cannot keep up.

By 2029, the world is projected to generate nearly 527.5 zettabytes of data while storage capacity will remain far behind. 

Amazon's AWS succeeded by treating infrastructure as real-time, computing.

Cloud wasn’t merely a product. It was operationalization to unprecedented large scale big data. 

Storage in Zettabyte 

527.5 zettabyte by 2029. 
19.3 storage of zettabyte by 2029. 

Nearly 96% ephemeral.

LLMs would emerge from knowledge stores to on the fly reasoning engines by 2029.

https://t.co/3BnHwtjhSS

items.title:
What surprised me most was the quality control loop.

→ Weak meshes get filtered out automatically
→...
items.content:
What surprised me most was the quality control loop.

→ Weak meshes get filtered out automatically
→ Hard cases like occlusions and odd lighting go back for expert refinement
→ For people, a consistent body rig keeps motion smooth across shots

That’s how this moves from demo to production.

items.title: @jaketaylor_mlb You bring up a good point. My point is that there's a Tesla in front of me that can ...
items.content:
@jaketaylor_mlb You bring up a good point. My point is that there's a Tesla in front of me that can see a bird and let everybody behind it know there's a bird in the road.

The front-facing camera is actually really good (even the former CEO admits that). Since cars generally go forward, they can see quite well, which is provable. My car handles objects in the road really well now; in fact, it goes around motorcycles coming toward you—which could have caused a head-on wreck—or other cars trying to pass someone on a two-lane road. It's really good at that and far faster at reacting to such things than a drunk driver would be, for instance.

I've been robbed, burglared, spit on, had girlfriends sexually harassed in Nethe...
items.content:
Delusional dataset

I've been robbed, burglared, spit on, had girlfriends sexually harassed in Netherlands by street thugs may times, many of my friends there too

I've never had any single bad thing happen to me in 10+ years of living in Asia (from Thailand to China to Korea to Japan)

Literally the worst thing was one Thai bodybuilder guy getting angry at me for not putting the weights back (which he should)

Asia is still a massive blindspot for Western datasets, which makes sense because they're all funded by Western countries

@_thomasip @XEng My list is long. I wish people would use lists more, and I wish I could talk to each list (like, "Hey, show me the top items in just this list").

As for the main algorithm, there are several problems with it:
1. Onboarding new users and getting them into the good stuff
2. Making the system smarter (in other words, presenting people and items that actually educate you and improve your life instead of just getting you to be triggered)

But we'll see. I'm trying to do my part by resharing good stuff, particularly news from the AI industry.

items.title:
From Stadium Networks to AI Coaches: How Tech Is Redefining Sports

Stadiums aren’t venues anymore—t...
items.content:
From Stadium Networks to AI Coaches: How Tech Is Redefining Sports

Stadiums aren’t venues anymore—they’re living networks.

In my latest article I explore this together with @TMobileBusiness as a partner to unpack how it works.

What’s changing (fast):

→ Connectivity = infrastructure. Ticketing, POS, broadcast, and crowd flow ride one wireless fabric. Less friction, faster ops, happier fans.

→ Broadcast explodes in perspectives. More angles, less latency, interactive feeds you can steer.

→ One network, many workloads. Dynamic bandwidth for what matters now—gate surges, replay reviews, merch spikes. 

→ Partnerships accelerate breakthroughs. Ref-cams, AR graphics, on-body antennas—none of these ships without tight cross-team engineering.

Check out the full article: https://t.co/wrx6ctysoL 

Cc: @EvanKirstel | @Chels_LA | @antgrasso | @HaroldSinnott |

You can fly an F16 or F35 but you can't shoot anything

I tried DCS World btw, it's the best combat flight sim, and it's really annoying to play

@MSFSofficial

items.title:
“Machine Learning” by Tom Mitchell — download PDF of this classic ML book here:
https://t.co/l2B7UG6...
items.content:
“Machine Learning” by Tom Mitchell — download PDF of this classic ML book here:
https://t.co/l2B7UG6trC

In 1998, when I read the first sentence in this book, I paused, reread it, and pondered “what sort of mathematics is this?”

I had many years of advanced math in physics undergrad and astrophysics grad school, but this was a totally new perspective for me. And it redirected the entire trajectory of my career.

One of the early products of my career redirection was this website that I created and maintained at @NASA for several years: "Data Mining Resources for Space Science" (shut down in 2002; now preserved on the Internet Archive Wayback Machine):
https://t.co/dAXGqZFHrr

items.title: @kylejune1415 @pbeisel @ti_morse More accurately, it's a fireable offense to talk to any journalist,...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer explains Apple's strict secrecy rules - employees can be fired just for talking to journalists
items.reasoning: Interesting industry context but not AI-specific
items.summary_html: Scobleizer explains Apple's strict secrecy rules - employees can be fired just for talking to journalists
items.content_html:
@kylejune1415 @pbeisel @ti_morse More accurately, it's a fireable offense to talk to any journalist, and I can't claim not to be a journalist. I have 550,000 followers here on X.

Employees are not allowed to speak in public, and this is part of the Apple rules where secrecy is job number one. Obviously, if they actually tell me anything about what's going on internally at Apple, that would totally be a fireable offense. However, I know people who have gotten fired just for talking to journalists without even saying anything (you're just not allowed to do that).

And the rules with journalists are that if you're off the record, you have to get the journalist to agree to be off the record before you start talking.

items.title: @pbeisel @nymbusjp @ti_morse I once had a whole page in The Economist magazine. The head of PR at Mi...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer shares career story about getting featured in The Economist while at Microsoft through blogging
items.reasoning: Interesting career anecdote but not AI-relevant
items.summary_html: Scobleizer shares career story about getting featured in The Economist while at Microsoft through blogging
items.content_html:
@pbeisel @nymbusjp @ti_morse I once had a whole page in The Economist magazine. The head of PR at Microsoft called me, somewhat angry, because he'd been trying for a decade to get something positive about Microsoft into The Economist. The thing is, that morning, I had no clue what The Economist magazine even was.

I was hired because of my blog, which was public, so I was paid to share Microsoft's internal secrets, if you will (although I was very careful not to share secrets most days). I've been interviewed by hundreds of journalists, and I always went in with my eyes open, knowing that I was taking a risk.

Usually, I even asked for permission or guidance. I certainly tried to figure out what the journalist was after before I talked to them. Anybody who works in the public space should know the rules and should have friends in PR so that they can get help if they're going to take something public.

...
items.content:
@jjcholo @BenSaul @ianshkreli @m1tch37 @PatrikSyk An extremely simple app implements from scratch:

1) LaTeX to Markdown conversion
2) The best on the market scientific OCR (PDF to Markdown) with support for figures, tables, references, bibliography, math
3) A novel reader that mixes traditional reading with conversations with an AI tutor
4) A WYSIWYG Markdown editor
5) A system that automatically discovers and uploads high-importance scientific content
6) Scales to thousands of concurrent users

This extremely simple app?

items.title:
Same in large parts of Europe

Europeans are NOT lazy

But the tax system here actively discourages ...
items.content:
Same in large parts of Europe

Europeans are NOT lazy

But the tax system here actively discourages people from working harder because it literally makes them poorer not richer

And it discourages businesses from hiring more people to grow their business because the increase in tax and bureaucracy costs more than the increase in profits

The end results is you have no new businesses and the only businesses that have remained are generational family businesses started before 1950 that are closely tied to national governments and those people and businesses actively support those high taxes and bureaucracy because by avoiding the creation of new businesses it keeps them in power

But the idiocy of this protectionism is that at of course if you 1) don't have new businesses bringing innovation, 2) you essentially protect your old businesses, you will soon get outcompeted by better products from outside Europe

Which is exactly what's now happening to the German car industry for example, and that's kinda symbolic for the rest of Europe's industries now

You could fix this overnight by the way: agressively lower taxes and bureaucracy on a pan-European level, easiest way to do that is create a virtual pan-European legal space where companies can legally register (aka the 28th regime) instead of existing in their national countries, as well as letting people be hired in that legal space

Just by the sheer benefits of that legal space you will see most companies move there, and in turn you will increase federalization of Europe into a US-like entity while at the same time making Europe one of the most attractive places to do business

Of course this likely won't happen because we have idiots in power now and no real democracy in Europe due to the terror of the European Comission

But if we wanted we could

items.title: The 1950s America was exceptional in every way imaginable: historically, politically, geographically...
items.content: The 1950s America was exceptional in every way imaginable: historically, politically, geographically, economically, etc. THAT is what needs explaining, not the other way around. The circumstances that lead to it will probably never obtain again. If mass home ownership and family formation in your 20s is the goal - and I fervently believe that it SHOULD be - then we need to approach it much more thoughtfully and deliberately, and not rely on accidents of history to recreate it.

items.title:
This is great news for Europe

28th regime means a virtual state where companies can register

The d...
items.content:
This is great news for Europe

28th regime means a virtual state where companies can register

The details approved are a bit unclear, but I hope it will include actual taxes and regulation too that fully override the national taxes and regulation for companies and staff hired

That would create a super attractive place to start and run startups similar to Delaware (or now increasingly Texas), the UK, and Singapore

And you don't have to change anything on a  national level per EU country, it exists besides it, but does compete with it but from a blank slate

👏

items.summary_html: Celebration of EU's 28th regime approval - a pan-European corporate registration framework
items.content_html:
This is great news for Europe

28th regime means a virtual state where companies can register

The details approved are a bit unclear, but I hope it will include actual taxes and regulation too that fully override the national taxes and regulation for companies and staff hired

That would create a super attractive place to start and run startups similar to Delaware (or now increasingly Texas), the UK, and Singapore

And you don't have to change anything on a national level per EU country, it exists besides it, but does compete with it but from a blank slate

👏

items.title: @NomadicScalperX @PathOfMen_ Speaking is a lot like swimming in ice-cold water. The first time you d...
items.content:
@NomadicScalperX @PathOfMen_ Speaking is a lot like swimming in ice-cold water. The first time you do it, you can barely breathe, but the more you do it, the more natural it becomes and the more fun you can have with it. It’s that sense of fun that really gets people entertained or educated.

Don Box taught me this. He actually came out on stage in a bathtub, mostly naked, one time—and people loved it!

items.title: Amazing historical fact 👉 Chemical engineer Harrison Ruffin Tyler was the last surviving grandson of...
items.content: Amazing historical fact 👉 Chemical engineer Harrison Ruffin Tyler was the last surviving grandson of the 10th U.S. President, John Tyler. Harrison died just 8 months ago, in late May 2025 at the age of 96. President Tyler, Harrison’s grandfather, was born 235 years earlier, in 1790, the second year of George Washington’s presidency.
